awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms for Cell Membrane Damage during Production of Biorenewable Fuels
awd_abstract_narration:
The conversion of plant biomass to biofuels by fermentation of biomass-derived sugars to alcohols is a sustainable route for renewable fuels production.  However, during the fermentation process, the biofuel molecules produced are often toxic to the fermenting organism at high concentrations, which lowers the overall biofuel production capacity.   One way to address this problem is redesign the membrane surrounding the fermenting cell, so that the organism can be more tolerant to high concentrations of biofuel dissolved in the liquid water surrounding it.  This collaborative project will develop a fundamental understanding of how biofuel molecules such as ethanol interact with the cell membrane of yeast, a fermenting microorganism.  The key innovation is use of sophisticated molecular dynamic simulation tools to model these interactions on computer. These studies will suggest strategies to target genetic engineering of the yeast cell to express cell membranes that improve the overall tolerance of the cell to high concentrations of biofuel, so that biofuel production is improved. The educational activities associated with this project include a middle- and high school outreach program designed to highlight how experiments and theory work together to solve important scientific problems, coordinated through programs at Iowa State University and the University of Maryland.

The overall goal of this collaborative research is to gain a fundamental understanding of the cellular and biomolecular interactions of the microbial membranes with model biofuel molecules known to influence membrane disruption.  The research will suggest how cell membranes can be engineered so that the cell is more tolerant to these biofuel molecules.  The research plan will focus on how Saccharomyces cerevisiae membranes interact with model biofuel molecules or intermediates, including ethanol, octanoic acid, and n-butanol.  These efforts will inform genetic engineering approaches to design cell membranes that improve the tolerance of the yeast cell to these biofuel molecules.  Key membrane metrics include porosity, fluidity, hydrophobicity and rigidity.  The research plan has three objectives. The first objective is to establish theoretical and experimental model membrane systems, using ethanol as a well-characterized model inhibitor.  The theoretical approach will use molecular dynamics simulations to reveal how the molecular character and lipid composition of the membrane influence ethanol-mediated membrane disruption.  The second objective is to probe the interaction of octanoic acid and n-butanol with model membrane systems developed under the first objective. More complex membrane systems will be considered to determine the effect of ergosterol, chain unsaturation, and lipid head groups on membrane disrupter toxicity.  Membrane vesicles assembled in vitro will be compared vesicles made from whole cells as well as intact whole cells to establish model membrane of lipid mixtures to living systems.  The third objective is to use molecular dynamics simulations to predict the improved tolerance of membranes with altered lipid head group concentrations, chain saturation, chain branching, and ergosterol concentration.  Membranes with improved tolerance will be tested in vitro and then expressed and tested in engineered S. cerevisiae cells.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The biomanufacturing of high volume/low value of fuels and chemicals struggles to economically compete with the petrochemical industry. The cost of a biomanufacturing process decreases if the microbial cell factory can produce the target molecule at a high concentration. These microbial cell factories are living creatures that often cannot tolerate the molecule concentrations that are needed for process economic viability. Sometimes, the target molecule interferes with the function of the microbial cell membrane. This interference could be in the form of causing the membrane to lose integrity and leak valuable energy-rich compounds from inside the cell. Or the interference could be in the form of altering the fluidity of the membrane. The membrane fluidity needs to be just right – not too solid and not too fluid – in order for the cell to be able to produce the target molecule. We can engineer the organism in order to change the composition of the membrane, so that it is more resistant to this interference. But we have a relatively poor understanding of what changes need to be made in order to increase membrane resistance to different types of chemicals.

Here, we developed a process for characterizing changes to the microbial cell membrane and its resistance to the damaging effects of several different alcohols. We are especially interested in strategies that enable increased resistance to n-butanol. n-butanol is a biofuel with properties superior to ethanol, but it is very damaging to the microbial cell membrane. If we can identify and implement changes that increase membrane tolerance to n-butanol, it would possibly lower the cost of n-butanol production. We also characterized and performed simulations of other aspects of the microbial cell membrane, its composition and its function.

The performance of this work provided the opportunity for graduate students, undergraduate students and a high school student to learn about the scientific process, the microbial cell membrane, how to design experiments, and how to report the results of their experiments in writing and in presentations. These students had the opportunity to attend scientific conferences and present their work to others. Some of these students were from Iowa State University, and some were students from smaller schools who participated in a summer research program at ISU. Professor Jarboe presented the results of this project to other professors, scientists and engineers at scientific conferences. We published several papers in peer-reviewed journals describing our work, and three more manuscripts are in preparation.

The project team participated in outreach programs for female high school students (“Taking the Road Less Traveled”), and a program for incoming ISU engineering students who are members of underrepresented groups (ISU’s Academic Program for Excellence for Engineers, APEXE).

The intellectual merit of this work is an increased understanding of strategies for increasing the robustness of the microbial cell membrane, with the goal of improving bioproduction.

The broader impacts of this work including training opportunities for the students involved in the project, communication of our results to others through publications and presentations, outreach to high school students and incoming ISU students, and the possibility of decreasing the cost of biomanufacturing of fuels and chemicals, such as n-butanol.

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2023
Modified by: Laura Jarboe
